Nevertheless, our method addresses key limitations of conventional signal and noise correlation estimators that persist even in high spiking rate and high SNR conditions.

Our proposed estimation framework can be used as groundwork for incorporating other notions of correlation such as the connected correlation function (Martin et al., 2020), and to account for non-Gaussian and higherÂ order structures arising from spatiotemporal interactions (Kadirvelu et al., 2017; Yu et al., 2011). Other possible extensions of this work include leveraging variational inference beyond the mean-field regime (Wang and Blei, 2013), extension to time-varying correlations that underlie rapid task-dependent dynamics, and extension to non-linear models such as those parameterized by neural networks (Aitchison et al., 2017). In the spirit of easing reproducibility, a MATLAB implementation of our proposed method as well as the data used in this work are made publicly available (Rupasinghe, 2020; Rupasinghe et al., 2021).

sec.title: Proposed forward model
sec.p: Suppose we observe fluorescence traces of N neurons, for a total duration of T discrete-time frames, corresponding to L independent trials of repeated stimulus. Let yt,l:=[yt,l(1),yt,l(2),â¯,yt,l(N)]â¤, zt,l:=[zt,l(1),zt,l(2),â¯,zt,l(N)]â¤, and nt,l:=[nt,l(1),nt,l(2),â¯,nt,l(N)]â¤ be the vectors of noisy observations, intracellular calcium concentrations, and ensemble spiking activities, respectively, at trial l and frame t. We capture the dynamics of ð²t,l by the following state-space model:ð²t,l=ðâ¢ð³t,l+ð°t,l,ð³t,l=Î±â¢ð³t-1,l+ð§t,l,where ðââNÃN represents the scaling of the observations, ð°t,l is zero-mean i.i.d. Gaussian noise with covariance ðºw, and 0â¤Î±<1 is the state transition parameter capturing the calcium dynamics through a first order model. Note that this state-space is non-Gaussian due to the binary nature of the spiking activity, thatÂ is, nt,l(j)â{0,1}. We model the spiking data as a point process or Generalized Linear Model with Bernoulli statistics (Eden et al., 2004; Paninski, 2004; Smith and Brown, 2003; Truccolo et al., 2005):nt,l(j)â¼Bernoulliâ¡(Î»t,l(j)),Î»t,l(j)=Ï(xt,l(j),djâ¤st),where Î»t,l(j) is the conditional intensity function (Truccolo et al., 2005), which we model as a non-linear function of the known external stimulus ð¬t and the other latent intrinsic and extrinsic trial-dependent covariates, xt,l:=[xt,l(1),xt,l(2),â¯,xt,l(N)]â¤. While we assume the stimulus ð¬tââM to be common to all neurons, we model the distinct effect of this stimulus on the jðð neuron via an unknown kernel ðjââM, akin to the receptive field.

The non-linear mapping of our choice is the logistic link, which is also the canonical link for a Bernoulli process in the point process and Generalized Linear Model frameworks (Truccolo et al., 2005). Thus, we assume:Ïâ¢(xt,l(j),ðjâ¤â¢ð¬t)=expâ¡(xt,l(j)+ðjâ¤â¢ð¬t)1+expâ¡(xt,l(j)+ðjâ¤â¢ð¬t).
Finally, we assume the latent trial dependent covariates to be a Gaussian process ð±t,lâ¼ð©â¢(ðx,ðºx), with mean Î¼x:=[Î¼x(1),Î¼x(2),â¯,Î¼x(N)]â¤ and covariance ðºx.

The probabilistic graphical model in Figure 8 summarizes the main components of the aforementioned forward model. According to this forward model, the underlying noise covariance matrix that captures trial-to-trial variability can be identified as ðºx. The signal covariance matrix, representing the covariance of the neural activity arising from the repeated application of the stimulus ð¬t, is given by ðºs:=ðâ¤â¢covâ¡(ð¬t,ð¬t)â¢ð, where D:=[d1,d2,â¯,dN]âRMÃN. The signal and noise correlation matrices, denoted by ð and ð, can then be obtained by standard normalization of ðºs and ðºx:(ð)i,j:=(ðºs)i,j(ðºs)i,i.(ðºs)j,j,(ð)i,j:=(ðºx)i,j(ðºx)i,i.(ðºx)j,j,âi,j=1,2,â¯,N.
The main problem is thus to estimate {ðºx,ð} from the noisy and temporally blurred data {ð²t,l}t=1,l=1T,L .

caption.title: Probabilistic graphical model of the proposed forward model.
caption.p: The fluorescence observations at the tðð time frame and lðð trial: ð²t,l, are noisy surrogates of the intracellular calcium concentrations: ð³t,l. The calcium concentration at time t is a function of the spiking activity ð§t,l, and the calcium activity at the previous time point ð³t-1,l. The spiking activity is driven by two independent mechanisms: latent trial-dependent covariates ð±t,l, and contributions from the known external stimulus ð¬t, which we model by ðâ¤â¢ð¬t (in which the receptive field ð is unknown). Then, we model ð±t,l as a Gaussian process with constant mean ðx, and unknown covariance ðºx. Finally, we assume the covariance ðºx to have an inverse Wishart prior distribution with hyper-parameters Ïx and Ïx. Based on this forward model, the inverse problem amounts to recovering the signal and noise correlations by directly estimating ðºx and ð (top layer) from the fluorescence observations {ð²t,l}t=1,l=1T,L (bottom layer).

sec.title: Overview of the proposed estimation method
sec.p: First, given a limited number of trials L from an ensemble with typically low spiking rates, we need to incorporate suitable prior assumptions to avoid overfitting. Thus, we impose a prior pððâ¢(ðºx) on the noise covariance, to compensate sparsity of data. A natural estimation method to estimate {ðºx,ð} in a Bayesian framework is to maximize the observed data likelihood p({yt,l}t,l=1T,L|Î£x,D), thatÂ is maximum likelihood (ML). Thus, we consider the joint likelihood of the observed data and latent processes to perform Maximum a Posteriori (MAP) estimation:(4)p(y,z,x,Î£x|D)=ppr(Î£x)ât,l=1T,L1(2Ï)N|Î£w|expâ¡(â12(yt,lâAzt,l)â¤Î£wâ1(yt,lâAzt,l))Ãât,l,j=1T,L,N(expâ¡(xt,l(j)+djâ¤st))zt,l(j)âÎ±ztâ1,l(j)1+expâ¡(xt,l(j)+djâ¤st)ât,l=1T,L1(2Ï)N|Î£x|expâ¡(â12(xt,lâÎ¼x)â¤Î£xâ1(xt,lâÎ¼x)).

Inspecting this MAP problem soon reveals that estimating ðºx and ð is a challenging task: (1) standard approaches such as Expectation-Maximization (EM) (Shumway and Stoffer, 1982) are intractable due to the complexity of the model, arising from the hierarchy of latent processes and the non-linearities involved in their mappings and (2) the temporal coupling of the likelihood in the calcium concentrations makes any potential direct solver scale poorly with T.

Thus, we propose an alternative solution based on Variational Inference (VI) (Beal, 2003; Blei et al., 2017; Jordan et al., 1999). VI is a method widely used in Bayesian statistics to approximate unwieldy posterior densities using optimization techniques, as a low-complexity alternative strategy to Markov Chain Monte Carlo sampling (Hastings, 1970) or empirical Bayes techniques such as EM. To this end, we treat {ð±t,l}t,l=1T,L and ðºx as latent variables and {ð³t,l}t,l=1T,L and ð as unknown parameters to be estimated. We introduce a framework to update the latent variables and parameters sequentially, with straightforward update rules. We will describe the main ingredients of the proposed framework in the following subsections. Hereafter, we use the shorthand notations ð²:={ð²t,l}t,l=1T,L, ð³:={ð³t,l}t,l=1T,L, and ð±:={ð±t,l}t,l=1T,L.

sec.title: Preliminary assumptions
sec.p: For the sake of simplicity, we assume that the constants Î±, ð, ðºw and ðx are either known or can be consistently estimated from pilot trials. Next, we take pððâ¢(ðºx) to be an Inverse Wishart density:ðºxâ¼InvWishNâ¡(ðx,Ïx),which turns out to be the conjugate prior in our model. Thus, ðx and Ïx will be the hyper-parameters of our model. Procedures for hyper-parameter tuning and choosing the key model parameters are given in subsections Hyper-parameter tuning and Guidelines for model parameter settings, respectively.

sec.title: Decoupling via PÃ³lya-Gamma augmentation
sec.p: Direct application of VI to problems containing both discrete and continuous random variables results in intractable densities. Specifically, finding a variational distribution for ð±t,l in our model with a standard distribution is not straightforward, due to the complicated posterior arising from co-dependent Bernoulli and Gaussian random variables. In order to overcome this difficulty, we employ PÃ³lya-Gamma (PG) latent variables (Pillow and Scott, 2012; Polson et al., 2013; Linderman et al., 2016). We observe from Equation 4 that the posterior density, pâ¢(ð±|ð³,ð,ðºx) is conditionally independent in t,l with:Â pâ¢(ð±t,l|ð³,ð,ðºx)âpâ¢(ð±t,l|ðºx)â¢âj=1N(expâ¡(xt,l(j)+ðjâ¤â¢ð¬t))zt,l(j)-Î±â¢zt-1,l(j)1+expâ¡(xt,l(j)+ðjâ¤â¢ð¬t).

Thus, upon careful inspection, we see that this density has the desired form for the PG augmentation scheme (Polson et al., 2013). Accordingly, we introduce a set of auxiliary PG-distributed i.i.d. latent random variables Ït,l:=[Ït,l(1),Ït,l(2),â¯,Ït,l(N)]â¤, Ït,l(j)â¼PGâ¡(1,0) for 1â¤jâ¤N, 1â¤tâ¤T and 1â¤lâ¤L, to derive the complete data log-likelihood:(5)logâ¡p(y,z,x,Ï,Î£x|D)=âTL2logâ¡|Î£x|+logâ¡ppr(Î£x)+ât,l=1T,L{â12(yt,lâAzt,l)â¤Î£wâ1(yt,lâAzt,l)â12(xt,lâÎ¼x)â¤Î£xâ1(xt,lâÎ¼x)+âj=1N{(zt,l(j)âÎ±ztâ1,l(j)â12)(xt,l(j)+djâ¤st)â12Ït,l(j)(xt,l(j)+djâ¤st)2+logâ¡pPG(1,0)(Ït,l(j))}}+C,where ð:={ðt,l}t,l=1T,L and C accounts for terms not depending on ð²,ð³,ð±,ð, ðºx and ð. The complete data log-likelihood is notably quadratic in ð³t,l, which as we show later admits efficient estimation procedures with favorable scaling in T.

sec.title: Deriving the optimal variational densities
sec.p: In this section, we will outline the procedure of applying VI to the latent variables ð±={ð±t,l}t,l=1T,L,ð={ðt,l}t,l=1T,L and ðºx, assuming that the parameter estimates ð³^ and ð^ of the previous iteration are available. The methods that we propose to update the parameters ð³^ and ð^ subsequently, will be discussed in the next section.

The objective of variational inference is to posit a family of approximate densities ð¬ over the latent variables, and to find the member of that family that minimizes the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence to the exact posterior:qâ(x,Ï,Î£x|z^,D^)=argminqâð¬KL(q(x,Ï,Î£x|z^,D^)âp(x,Ï,Î£x|y,z^,D^)).

However, evaluating the KL divergence is intractable, and it has been shown (Blei et al., 2017) that an equivalent result to this minimization can be obtained by maximizing the alternative objective function, called the evidence lower bound (ELBO):ELBO(q)=E[logâ¡p(x,Ï,Î£x,y|z^,D^)]âE[logâ¡q(x,Ï,Î£x|z^,D^)].

Further, we assume ð¬ to be a mean-field variational family (Blei et al., 2017), resulting in the overall variational density of the form:(6)qâ¢(ð±,ð,ðºx)=qâ¢(ðºx)â¢ât,l=1T,L(qâ¢(ð±t,l)â¢âj=1Nqâ¢(Ït,l(j))).

Under the mean field assumptions, the maximization of the ELBO can be derived using the optimization algorithm âCoordinate Ascent Variational Inferenceâ (CAVI) (Bishop, 2006; Blei et al., 2017). Accordingly, we see that the optimal variational densities in Equation 6 take the forms:logqâ(xt,l)âEqâ(Î£x)qâ(Ït,l)[logâ¡p(xt,l|Ït,l,Î£x,y,z^,D^)],logqâ(Ït,l(j))âEqâ(xt,l)[logâ¡p(Ït,l(j)|xt,l,Î£x,y,z^,D^)],logqâ(Î£x)âEqâ(x)[logâ¡p(Î£x|x,y,z^,D^)].

Upon evaluation of these expectations, we derive the optimal variational distributions as:qâ(xt,l)â¼ð©(mxt,l,Qxt,l),qâ(Ït,l(j))â¼PGâ¡(1,ct,l(j)),qâ(Î£x)â¼InvWishN(Px,Î³x),whose parameters mxt,l:=[mxt,l(1),mxt,l(2),â¯,mxt,l(N)]T, ðð±t,l, ct,l(j), ðx, and Î³x can be updated given parameter estimates ð^ and ð³^:Qxt,l=(Î©~t,l+Î³xPxâ1)â1,mxt,l=Qxt,l(z^t,lâÎ±z^tâ1,lâ121âÎ©~t,lD^â¤st+Î³xPxâ1Î¼x),Px:=Ïx+ât,l=1T,L{Qxt,l+mxt,lmxt,lâ¤âÎ¼xmxt,lâ¤âmxt,lÎ¼xâ¤+Î¼xÎ¼xâ¤},ct,l(j)=(Qxt,l)j,j+(mxt,l(j)+d^jâ¤st)2,andÂ Î³x:=Ïx+Tâ¢L, with Î©~t,lâRNÃN denoting a diagonal matrix with entries (Î©~t,l)j,j:=12ct,l(j)tanhâ¡(ct,l(j)2) and ðââN denoting the vector of all ones.

sec.title: Low-complexity parameter updates
sec.p: Note that even though ð³ is composed of the latent processes ð³t,l, we do not use VI for its inference, and instead consider it as an unknown parameter. This choice is due to the temporal dependencies arising from the underlying state-space model in Equation 4, which hinders a proper assignment of variational densities under the mean field assumption. We thus seek to estimate both ð³ and ð using the updated variational density q*â¢(ð±,ð,ðºx).

First, note that the log-likelihood in Equation 5 is decoupled in l, which admits independent updates to {ð³t,l}t=1T, for l=1,â¯,L. As such, given an estimate ð^, we propose to estimate {ð³t,l}t=1T as:

{z^t,l}t=1T=argmax{zt,l}t=1TEqâ(x,Ï,Î£x)[logâ¡p(y,z,x,Ï,Î£x|D^)]=argmin{zt,l}t=1Tât=1T{12(yt,lâAzt,l)â¤Î£wâ1(yt,lâAzt,l)ââj=1N(mxt,l(j)+d^jâ¤st)(zt,l(j)âÎ±ztâ1,l(j))}, under the constraints 0â¤zt,l(j)âÎ±ztâ1,l(j)â¤1, for t=1,â¯,T and j=1,â¯,N. These constraints are a direct consequence of nt,l(j)=zt,l(j)-Î±â¢zt-1,l(j) being a Bernoulli random variable with ð¼â¢[nt,l(j)]â[0,1]. While this problem is a quadratic program and can be solved using standard techniques, it is not readily decoupled in t, and thus standard solvers would not scale favorably in T.

Instead, we consider an alternative solution that admits a low-complexity recursive solution by relaxing the constraints. To this end, we relax the constraint ð³t,l-Î±â¢ð³t-1,lâª¯ð and replace the constraint ð³t,l-Î±â¢ð³t-1,lâª° by penalty terms proportional to |zt,l(j)-Î±â¢zt-1,l(j)|. The resulting relaxed problem is thus given by:(7)min{ð³t,l}t=1Tâât=1T{12â¢(ð²t,l-ðð³t,l)â¤â¢ðºw-1â¢(ð²t,l-ðð³t,l)+âj=1NÎ½t,l(j)â¢|zt,l(j)-Î±â¢zt-1,l(j)|},where Î½t,l(j):=Î²â¢|mð±t,l(j)+ð^jâ¤â¢ð¬t| with Î²â¥1 being a hyper-parameter. Given that the typical spiking rates are quite low in practice, mð±t,l(j)+ð^jâ¤â¢ð¬t is expected to be a negative number. Thus, we have assumed that -mð±t,l(j)-ð^jâ¤â¢ð¬t=|mð±t,l(j)+ð^jâ¤â¢ð¬t|.

The problem of Equation 7 pertains to compressible state-space estimation, for which fast recursive solvers are available (Kazemipour et al., 2018). The solver utilizes the Iteratively Re-weighted Least Squares (IRLS) (Ba et al., 2014) framework to transform the absolute value in the second term of the cost function into a quadratic form in ð³t,l, followed by Fixed Interval Smoothing (FIS) (Rauch et al., 1965) to find the minimizer. At iteration k, given a current estimate ð³[k-1], the problem reduces to a Gaussian state-space estimation of the form:(8)ð²t,l=ðð³t,l+ð°t,l,ð³t,l=Î±â¢ð³t-1,l+ð¯t,l,with ð°t,lâ¼ð©â¢(0,ðºw) and ð¯t,lâ¼ð©â¢(0,ðºð¯t,l[k]), where ðºð¯t,l[k]ââNÃN is a diagonal matrix with (ðºð¯t,l[k])j,j:=(z^t,l(j)â¢[k-1]-Î±â¢z^t-1,l(j)â¢[k-1])2+Îµ2/Î½t,l(j), for some small constant Îµ>0. This problem can be efficiently solved using FIS, and the iterations proceed for a total of K times or until a standard convergence criterion is met (Kazemipour et al., 2018). It is noteworthy that our proposed estimator of the calcium concentration ð³t,l can be thought of as soft spike deconvolution, which naturally arises from our variational framework, as opposed to the hard spike deconvolution step used in two-stage estimators.

Finally, given q*â¢(ð±,ð,ðºx) and the updated ð³^, the estimate of ðj for j=1,2,â¯,N can be updated in closed-form by maximizing the expected complete log-likelihood ð¼q*â¢(ð±,ð,ðºx)â¢[logâ¡pâ¢(ð²,ð³^,ð±,ð,ðºx|ð)]:d^j=(ât,l=1T,L((Î©~t,l)j,jststâ¤))â1(ât,l=1T,L{(z^t,l(j)âÎ±z^tâ1,l(j)â12)stâ(Î©~t,l)j,jmxt,l(j)st}).

The VI procedure iterates between updating the variational densities and parameters until convergence, upon which we estimate the noise and signal covariances as:ðº^x:=modeâ¡{q*â¢(ðºx)}=ðxÎ³x+N+1,ðº^s:=ð^â¤â¢ð¼â¢[ð¬tâ¢ð¬tâ¤]â¢ð^.

The overall combined iterative procedure is outlined in Algorithm 1. Furthermore, a MATLAB implementation of this algorithm is publicly available in Rupasinghe, 2020. It is worth noting that a special case of our proposed variational inference procedure can be used to estimate signal and noise correlations from electrophysiology recordings. Given that spiking activity, thatÂ is {ð§t,l}t,l=1T,L, is directly observed in this case, the solution to the optimization problem in Equation (7) is no longer required. Thus, the parameters ðºx and ð can be estimated using a simplified variational procedure, which is outlined in Algorithm 2 in Appendix 3.

sec.title: Guidelines for model parameter settings
sec.p: There are several key model parameters that need to be set by the user prior to the application of our proposed method. Here, we provide our rationale and criteria for choosing these parameters, which could also serve as guidelines in facilitating the applicability and adoption of our method by future users. We will also provide the specific choices of these parameters used in our simulation studies and real data analyses.

sec.title: Number of neurons selected for the analysis (N)
sec.p: While our proposed method scales-up well with the population size due to low-complexity update rules involved, including neurons with negligible spiking activity in the analysis would only increase the complexity and potentially contaminate the correlation estimates. Thus, we performed an initial pre-processing step to extract N neurons that exhibited at least one spiking event in at least half of the trials considered.

sec.title: Stimulus integration window length (R)
sec.p: The number of lags R considered in stimulus integration is a key parameter that can be set through data-driven approaches or using prior domain knowledge. Examples of common data-driven criteria include cross-validation, Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) and Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), which balance the estimation accuracy and model complexity (Arlot and Celisse, 2010; Ding et al., 2018).

To quantify the effect of R on model complexity, we first describe the stimulus encoding model in our framework. Suppose that the onset of the pðð tone in the stimulus set (p=1,â¯,P, where P is the number of distinct tones) is given by a binary sequence ft(p)â{0,1}. The choice of R implies that the response at time t post-stimulus depends only on the R most recent time lags. As such, the effective stimulus at time t corresponding to tone p is given by ð¬t(p):=[ft(p),ft-1(p),â¯,ft-R+1(p)]â¤ââR. By including all the P tones, the overall effective stimulus at the ttâ¢h time frame is given by ð¬t:=[ð¬t(1)â¤,â¯,ð¬t(P)â¤]â¤ââRâ¢P. The stimulus modulation vector ðj would thus be Râ¢P-dimensional. As a result, the number of parameters (M=Râ¢P) to be estimated linearly increases with R. By using additional domain knowledge, we chose R to be large enough to capture the stimulus effects, and at the same time to be small enough to control the complexity of the algorithm.

As an example, given that the typical tone response duration of mouse primary auditory neurons is <1 s (Linden et al., 2003; DeWeese et al., 2003; Petrus et al., 2014), with a sampling frequency of fs=30 Hz, a choice of Râ¼30 would suffice to capture the stimulus effects. By further examining the effect of varying R on the proposed correlation estimates in Figure 4âfigure supplement 1, we chose R=25 for our real data analyses.

sec.title: Observation noise covariance (ðºw) and scaling matrix (ð)
sec.p: We assumed that the observation noise covariance ðºw is diagonal, and estimated the diagonal elements using the background fluorescence in the absence of spiking events, for each neuron. We set ð=aâ¢ð, where ðââNÃN represents the identity matrix, and estimated a by considering the average increase in fluorescence after the occurrence of isolated spiking events. Specifically, we derived the average fluorescence activity of multiple trials triggered to the fluorescence rise onset, and set a as the increment in the magnitude of this average fluorescence immediately following the rise onset.

sec.title: State transition parameter (Î±)
sec.p: We chose Î± in the range [0.95,0.98], which match the slow dynamics of the calcium indicator in our data. We tested the robustness of our estimates under different choices of Î± in this range through the method outlined in Hyper-parameter tuning, and accordingly chose the optimal value of Î±.

sec.title: Mean of the latent trial-dependent process (ðx)
sec.p: We estimated ðx as a constant that is proportional to the average firing rate. To this end, we parametrized each component of ðx as Î¼x(j)=-aÎ¼+bÎ¼â¢1Lâ¢Tâ¢ât,l=1T,Lyt,l(j), for j=1,â¯,N. The constants aÎ¼ and bÎ¼ were chosen such that -2â¤Î¼x(j)â¤-10, which gives the range of baseline parameters compatible with observed firing rates in our experimental data.

sec.title: Parameter choices for simulation study 1
sec.p: In the first simulation study, we set Î±=0.98, Î²=8, ð=0.1â¢ð, ðx=-4.51 and ðºw=2Ã10-4â¢ð (ðââ8Ã8 represents the identity matrix and ðââ8 represents the vector of all ones), so that the SNR of simulated data was in the same range as that of experimentally-recorded data. We used a 6ðð order autoregressive process with a mean of -1 as the stimulus (st), and considered R=2 (M=2) lags of the stimulus (i.e. ð¬t=[st,st-1]â¤) in both the generative model and inference procedure. The components of the linear and quadratic stimulus modulation vectors, thatÂ is ðj, ð~j,1 and ð~j,2, were chosen at random uniformly in the range [-0.5,0.5]. The variance of st was set in each case such that the average power of the overall signal component (ðjâ¤â¢ð¬t for the linear model, and ðjâ¤â¢ð¬t+(ð~j,1â¤â¢ð¬t)2+(ð~j,2â¤â¢ð¬t)2 for the non-linear model) was comparable to the average power of the noise component (xt,l(j)).

sec.title: Parameter choices for simulation study 2
sec.p: In the second simulation study, we set Î±=0.98, ð=0.1â¢ð, ðx=-4.51 and ðºw=10-4â¢ð (ðââ30Ã30 represents the identity matrix and ðââ30 represents the vector of all ones) when generating the fluorescence traces {ð²t,l}t,l=1T,L, so that the SNR of the simulated data was in the same range as of real calcium imaging observations. Furthermore, we simulated the spike trains based on a Poisson process (Smith and Brown, 2003) using the discrete time re-scaling procedure (Brown et al., 2002; Smith and Brown, 2003). Following the assumptions in Brown et al., 2002, we used an exponential link to simulate the observations:nt,l(j)â¼Poisson(Î»t,l(j)),Î»t,l(j)=expâ¡(xt,l(j)),as opposed to the Bernoulli-logistic assumption in our recognition model. Then, we estimated the noise covariance ðº^x using the Algorithm 1, with a slight modification. Since there are no external stimuli, we set ð¬t= and ð=. Accordingly, in Algorithm 1, we initialized ð^= and did not perform the update on ð^ in the subsequent iterations.

sec.title: Parameter choices for real data study 1
sec.p: The dataset consisted of recordings from 371 excitatory neurons, from which we selected N=16 responsive neurons for the analysis. Each trial consisted of T=3600 time frames (the sampling frequency was 30 Hz, and each trial had a duration of 120 s), with the presentation of a random sequence of four tones (P=4). The spiking events were very sparse and infrequent, and hence this dataset fits our model with at most one spiking event in a time frame.

We considered R=25 (M=100) time lags in this analysis and further examined the effect of varying R in Figure 4âfigure supplement 1. We set Î±=0.95 and ð=ð (ðââ16Ã16 represents the identity matrix).

sec.title: Parameter choices for real data study 2
sec.p: Each trial consisted of T=765 frames (25.5 s) at a sampling frequency of 30 Hz. The A1 neurons studied here had low response rates (in both time and space), with only â¼10 neurons exhibiting spiking activity in at least half of the trials. Thus, we selected N=10 neurons and L=10 trials for the analysis, and chose R=25 lags of the stimulus (M=25) in the model for the stimulus-driven condition. We set Î±=0.95 and ð=0.75â¢ð (ðââ10Ã10 represents the identity matrix).

sec.title: Parameter choices for real data study 3
sec.p: Each experiment consisted of L=5 trials of P=9 different tone frequencies repeated at four different amplitude levels, resulting in each concatenated trial being â¼180 s long (see Bowen et al., 2020 for more details). We set the number of stimulus time lags considered to be R=25 (M=225). For each layer, we analyzed fluorescence observations from six experiments. In each experiment, we selected the most responsive Nâ¼20 neurons for the subsequent analysis. We set Î±=0.95 and ð=ð.

sec.title: Simulation studies
sec.p: Since the ground truth is known in simulations, we directly compared the performance of each signal and noise correlation estimate with the ground truth signal and noise correlations, respectively. Suppose the ground truth correlations are given by the matrix ð and the estimated correlations are given by the matrix ð^. To quantify the similarity between ð and ð^, we defined the following two metrics:
Normalized Mean Squared Error (NMSE): The NMSE computes the mean squared error of ð^ with respect to ð using the Frobenius Norm:NMSE:=âXâX^âF2âXâF2.

Ratio between out-of-network power and in-network power (leakage): First, we identified the in-network and out-of-network components from the ground truth correlation matrix ð. Suppose that if the true correlation between the iðð neuron and the jðð neuron is non-zero, then |(ð)i,j|>Î´x, for some Î´x>0. Thus, we formed a matrix ððð that masks the in-network components, by setting (ððð)i,j=1 if |(ð)i,j|>Î´x and (ððð)i,j=0 if |(ð)i,j|â¤Î´x. Likewise, we also formed a matrix ðððð that masks the out-of-network components, by setting (ðððð)i,j=1 if |(ð)i,j|â¤Î´x and (ðððð)i,j=0 if |(ð)i,j|>Î´x. Then, using these two matrices we quantified the leakage effect of ð^ comparative to ð by:leakage:=â¥ð^â ððððâ¥F2â¥ð^â ðððâ¥F2,where (â ) denotes element-wise multiplication.

sec.title: Real data studies
sec.p: To quantify the similarity and dissimilarity between signal and noise correlation estimates, we used a statistic based on the Tanimoto similarity metric (Lipkus, 1999), denoted by Tsâ¢(ð,ð) for two matrices ð and ð. For two vectors ð and ð with non-negative entries, the Tanimoto coefficient (Lipkus, 1999) is defined as:T(a,b):=aTbaTa+bTbâaTb.

The Tanimoto similarly metric between two matrices can be defined in a similar manner, by vectorizing the matrices. Thus, we formulated a similarity metric between two correlation matrices ð and ð as follows. Let ð+:=maxâ¡{ð,0â¢ð} and ð-:=maxâ¡{-ð,0â¢ð}, with the maxâ¡{â ,â } operator interpreted element-wise. Note that ð=ð+-ð-, and ð+,ð- have non-negative entries. We then defined the similarity matrix by combining those of the positive and negative parts as follows:Tsâ¢(ð,ð):=Îµâ¢Tâ¢(ð+,ð+)+(1-Îµ)â¢Tâ¢(ð-,ð-)where Îµâ[0,1] denotes the percentage of positive entries in ð and ð. As a measure of dissimilarity, we used Tdâ¢(ð,ð):=1-Tsâ¢(ð,ð). The values of Tdâ¢(ð^,ð^) in Table 1 and Tsâ¢(ð^ðððð,ð^ðððð) and Tdâ¢(ð^ðððð,ð^ðððð) reported in Table 2 were obtained based on the foregoing definitions.

To further assess the statistical significance of these results, we performed following randomized tests. To test the significance of Tsâ¢(ð^ðððð,ð^ðððð), for each comparison and each algorithm, we fixed the first matrix (i.e. ð^ðððð) and randomly shuffled the entries of the second one (i.e.Â ð^ðððð) while respecting symmetry. We repeated this procedure for 10000 trials, to derive the null distributions that represented the probabilities of chance occurrence of similarities between two random groups of neurons.

To test the significance of Tdâ¢(ð^,ð^) and Tdâ¢(ð^ðððð,ð^ðððð), for each comparison and each algorithm, again we fixed the first matrix (i.e. signal correlations). Then, we formed the elements of the second matrix (akin to noise correlations) as follows. For each element of the second matrix, we assigned either the same element as the signal correlations (in order to model the leakage effect) or a random noise (with same variance as the elements in the noise correlation matrix) with equal probability. As before, we repeated this procedure for 10,000 trials, to derive the null distributions that represent the probabilities of chance occurrence of dissimilarities between two matrices that have some leakage between them.

sec.title: Hyper-parameter tuning
sec.p: The hyper-parameters that directly affect the proposed estimation are the inverse Wishart prior hyper-parameters: Ïx and Ïx. Given that Ïx appears in the form of Î³x:=Tâ¢L+Ïx, we will consider Ïx and Î³x as the main hyper-parameters for simplicity. Here, we propose a criterion for choosing these two hyper-parameters in a data-driven fashion, which will then be used to construct the estimates of the noise covariance matrix ðº^x and weight matrix ð^. Due to the hierarchy of hidden layers in our model, an empirical Bayes approach for hyper-parameter selection using a likelihood-based performance metric is not straightforward. Hence, we propose an alternative empirical method for hyper-parameter selection as follows.

For a given choice of ðx and Î³x, we estimate ðº^x and ð^ following the proposed method. Then, based on the generative model in Proposed forward model, and using the estimated values of ðº^x and ð^, we sample an ensemble of simulated fluorescence traces ð²^={ð²^t(l)}t,l=1T,L, and compute the metric dâ¢(ðx,Î³x):d(Ïx,Î³x):=Dfrob(covâ¡(y^,y^),covâ¡(y,y)),where covâ¡(â ,â ) denotes the empirical covariance and Dð¿ððð»â¢(ð,ð):=â¥ð-ðâ¥F2. Note that Dð¿ððð»â¢(ð,ð) is strictly convex in ð. Thus, minimizing Dð¿ððð»â¢(ð,ð) over ð for a given ð has a unique solution. Accordingly, we observe that dâ¢(ðx,Î³x) is minimized when covâ¡(ð²^,ð²^) is nearest to covâ¡(ð²,ð²). Therefore, the corresponding estimates ðº^x and ð^ that generated ð²^, best match the second-order statistics of ð² that was generated by the true parameters ðºx and ð.

The typically low spiking rate of sensory neurons observed in practice may render the estimation problem ill-posed. It is thus important to have an accurate choice of the scale matrix ðx in the prior distribution. However, an exhaustive search for optimal tuning of ðx is not computationally feasible, given that it has Nâ¢(N+1)/2 free variables. Thus, the main challenge here is finding the optimal choice of the scale matrix ðx,ððð.

To address this challenge, we propose the following method. First, we fix ðx,ðððð=Ïâ¢ð, where Ï is a scalar and ðââNÃN is the identity matrix. Next, given ðx,ðððð we find the optimal choice of Î³x as:Î³x,ðððð=argminÎ³xâð®Î³â¢dâ¢(ðx,ðððð,Î³x),where ð®Î³ is a finite set of candidate solutions for Î³x>N-1. Let ðº^x,ðððð denote the noise covariance estimate corresponding to hyper-parameters (ðx,ðððð,Î³x,ðððð). We will next use ðº^x,ðððð to find a suitable choice of ðx. To this end, we first fix Î³x,ððð:=Tâ¢L+Ï~x, for some N-1<Ï~xâªTâ¢L. Note that by choosing Ï~x to be much smaller than Tâ¢L, the final estimates become less sensitive to the choice of Î³x. Then, we construct a candidate set ð®Ï for ðx,ððð by scaling Î£^x,init with a finite set of scalars Î·âR+,Â i.e.Â ð®Ï:={Î·Î£^x,init,Î·âR+}. To select ðx,ððð, we match it with the choice of Î³x,ððð by solving:ðx,ððð=argminðxâð®Ïâ¢dâ¢(ðx,Î³x,ððð).
Finally, we use these hyper-parameters (ðx,ððð,Î³x,ððð) to obtain the estimators ðº^x and ð^ as the output of the algorithm.

sec.title: Experimental procedures
sec.p: All procedures were approved by the University of Maryland Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. Imaging experiments were performed on a P60 (for real data study 1) and P83 (for real data study 2) female F1 offspring of the CBA/CaJ strain (The Jackson Laboratory; stock #000654) crossed with transgenic C57BL/6J-Tg(Thy1-GCaMP6s)GP4.3Dkim/J mice (The Jackson Laboratory; stock #024275) (CBAxThy1), and F1 (CBAxC57). The third real data study was performed on data from P66-P93 and P166-P178 mice (see Bowen et al., 2020 for more details). We used the F1 generation of the crossed mice because they have good hearing into adulthood (Frisina et al., 2011).

We performed cranial window implantation and two-photon imaging as previously described in Francis et al., 2018; Liu et al., 2019; Bowen et al., 2019. Briefly, we implanted a cranial window of 3 mm in diameter over the left auditory cortex. We used a scanning microscope (Bergamo II series, B248, Thorlabs) coupled to Insight X3 laser (Spectra-physics) (study 1) or pulsed femtosecond Ti:Sapphire two-photon laser with dispersion compensation (Vision S, Coherent) (studies 2 and 3) to image GCaMP6s fluorescence from individual neurons in awake head-fixed mice with an excitation wavelengths of Î»=920 nm and Î»=940 nm, respectively. The microscope was controlled by ThorImageLS software. The size of the field of view was 370Ã370Î¼m. Imaging frames of 512Ã512 pixels (pixel size 0.72Î¼m) were acquired at 30 Hz by bidirectional scanning of an 8 kHz resonant scanner. The imaging depth was around 200Î¼m below pia.

sec.title: Data pre-processing
sec.p: A circular ROI was manually drawn over each cell body to extract raw fluorescence traces from individual cells. Neuropil contamination subtraction and baseline correction were performed on the raw fluorescence traces of each cell (Francis et al., 2018; Liu et al., 2019; Bowen et al., 2020) according to Fð¼ð¾ð ð -Î±nâ¢Fðð¾ðððððð -baselinebaseline, where Î±n was set to 0.7 in real data study 1 (Francis et al., 2018), 0.8 in real data study 2 (Liu et al., 2019) and 0.9 in real data study 3 (Bowen et al., 2020). The two-photon observations {ð²t,l}t,l=1T,L used in our analyses are the output of this pre-processing step.

sec.title: Stimuli for real data study 1
sec.p: During imaging experiments, we presented four tones (4, 8, 16, and 32 kHz) at 70 dB SPL. The tones were 2 s in duration with an inter-trial silence of 4 s. For the sequence of tones, we first generated a randomized sequence that consisted of five repeats for each tone (20 tones in total) and then the same sequence was repeated for 10 trials.

sec.title: Stimuli for real data study 2
sec.p: During imaging experiments, we presented a 75 dB SPL 100 ms broadband noise (4â48 kHz) as the auditory stimulus. Each trial was 5.1 s long (1 s pre-stimulus silence + 0.1 s stimulus + 3 s post-stimulus silence), and the inter-trial duration was 3 s. Spontaneous neuronal activity was collected from activity during randomly interleaved no-stimuli trials of the same duration, and these trials had complete silence throughout the trial duration (5.1 s long).

Then, we extracted 50 such trials from each type, and formed 10 (L=10) trials each of 25.5 s duration (T=765 frames) for the subsequent analysis, by concatenating five 5.1 s trials. This final step was performed to increase the effective trial duration.

sec.title: Stimuli for real data study 3
sec.p: During imaging experiments, sounds were played at four sound levels (20, 40, 60, and 80 dB SPL). Auditory stimuli consisted of sinusoidal amplitude-modulated (SAM) tones (20 Hz modulation, cosine phase), ranging from 3 to 48 kHz. The frequency resolution was two tones/octave (0.5 octave spacing) and each of these tonal stimuli was 1 s long, repeated five times with a 4â6 s inter-stimulus interval (see Bowen et al., 2020 for details).

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors thank Daniel E Winkowski for collecting the data in Bowen et al., 2019 that was also used in this work.

sec.title: Data availability
sec.p: A MATLAB implementation of the proposed method has been archived in Github at https://github.com/Anuththara-Rupasinghe/Signal-Noise-Correlation (copy archived at https://archive.softwareheritage.org/swh:1:rev:7397cc8d751a128f41df81f8af160014b22974d6). The data used in this work have been deposited in the Digital Repository at the University of Maryland at http://hdl.handle.net/1903/26917.

Accordingly, we see that:(Î£xcon)i,jâCN1Lâlcov(xt,l(i)âÎ¼x(i),xt,l(j)âÎ¼x(j))+Î¾t,l=CN(Î£x)i,j+Î¾t,l,where CN is a constant and Î¾t,l is typically small if the latent process ð±t,l and the stimulus ð¬t are concentrated around their means. Then, the noise correlations are derived by normalization of the noise covariance given in Equation 9. This cancels out the scaling factor CN, and we get:(ðð¼ðð)i,jâââ(ð)i,j.
Thus, we similarly conclude that as T,Lââ, the conventional definition of noise correlation ðð¼ðð indeed aims to approximate ð.

As a numerical illustration, we demonstrated in Figure 2âfigure supplement 2 that the conventional definitions of the correlations indeed approximate our proposed definitions, but require much larger number of trials to be accurate. More specifically, in order to achieve comparable performance to our method using L=20 trials, the conventional correlation estimates require L=1000 trials.

sec.title: Proof of Theorem 1
sec.p: In what follows, we present a comprehensive proof of Theorem 1. Recall the following key assumptions:

Assumption (1). We assume a scalar time-varying external stimulus (i.e. ð¬t=st, and hence ðj=dj,ð=[d1,d2,â¯,dN]â¤ ). Furthermore, we set the observation noise covariance to be ðºw=Ïw2â¢ð, for notational convenience.

Assumption (2). We derive the performance bounds in the regime where T and L are large, and thus do not impose any prior distribution on the correlations (i.e. pððâ¢(ðºx)â1), which are otherwise needed to mitigate overfitting (see Preliminary assumptions).

Assumption (3). We assume the latent trial-dependent process and stimulus to be slowly varying signals, and thus adopt a piece-wise constant model in which these processes are constant within consecutive windows of length W (i.e., ð±t,l=ð±Wk,l and st=sWk, for (k-1)â¢W+1â¤t<kâ¢W and k=1,â¯,K with Wk=(k-1)â¢W+1 and Kâ¢W=T) for our theoretical analysis, as is usually done in spike count calculations for conventional noise correlation estimates.

Note that we have re-defined the latent process ð±t,l by absorbing the stimulus activity stâ¢ð to the mean of ð±t,l for notational convenience, without loss of generality. Hereafter, we also assume that ð=ð without loss of generality. We have:(13)hnum(1)â¢(ð§^)=â«rnum(1)â¢(ð±)â¢expâ¡(A2â¢f2â¢(ð±))â¢ðð±,where f2â¢(ð±)=âk,l,j(n~Wk,l(j)â¢xWk,l(j)-logâ¡(1+expâ¡(xWk,l(j)))) withn~Wk,l=[n~Wk,l(1),n~Wk,l(2),â¯,n~Wk,l(N)]â¤:=1Wâw=1Wn^(kâ1)W+w,l,rnum(1)(x)=1(2Ï)(W+1)KLNÏw2TNL|Î£x|KLexpâ¡(â12ât(xWk,lâÎ¼xâsWkd)â¤Î£xâ1(xWk,lâÎ¼xâsWkd))Ã(1Lâk=1KsWk2âk=1KsWk,l(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j))),andÂ A2=W. Then, we note that the gradient of f2, ââ¡f2â¢(ð±^)= for ð±^:={x^Wk,l(j)=Ï-1(n~Wk,l(j))}k,l,j=1K,L,N, where Ï-1â¢(z):=logitâ¡(z)=lnâ¡(z/(1-z)). Accordingly, by re-applying the saddle point method of asymptotic expansions, we evaluate the integral in Equation 13 as:(14)hnum(1)â¢(ð§^)=rnum(1)â¢(ð±^)Ãexpâ¡(A2â¢f2â¢(ð±^))â¢(2â¢Ï)Kâ¢Lâ¢N-A2â¢|Hâ¢(f2â¢(ð±^))|â¢(1+ðªâ¢(1A2)),where the determinant of the Hessian, |Hâ¢(f2â¢(ð±^))|=-âk,l,jn~Wk,l(j)â¢(1-n~Wk,l(j))<0 when conditioned on event ðW. The higher order terms in Equation 14 will be bounded if the covariance of the saddle point approximation (-(Hâ¢(f2â¢(ð±^)))-1) is bounded, which we ensure by conditioning on event ðW. This completes the evaluation of Inum(1).

Following the same sequence of arguments, we evaluate the denominator of Equation 10 denoted by Iden(1). Accordingly, we derive:(15)Iden(1)=hden(1)(n^)Ãexpâ¡(A1f1(n^))(2Ï)TLNâA1|H(f1)|(1+ðª(1A1)),hden(1)(n^)=rden(1)(x^)Ãexpâ¡(A2f2(x^))(2Ï)KLNâA2|H(f2(x^))|(1+ðª(1A2)),where rden(1)(x)=1(2Ï)(W+1)KLNÏw2TNL|Î£x|KLexpâ¡(â12âk,l(xWk,lâÎ¼xâsWkd)â¤Î£xâ1(xWk,lâÎ¼xâsWkd)). Finally, by combining Equation 12, Equation 14 and Equation 15, the maximum likelihood estimator in Equation 10 takes the form:d^j=Inum(1)Iden(1)=d~j(1+ðª(1A1))(1+ðª(1A2))(1+ðª(1A1))(1+ðª(1A2))=d~j(1+ðª(Ïw2))(1+ðª(1W)).

Further, following the same sequence of reasoning, simplifying the numerator (Inum(2)) and denominator (Iden(2)) of Equation 11 yields:(ðº^x)i,j=Inum(2)Iden(2)=(ðº~x)i,jâ¢(1+ðªâ¢(1A1))â¢(1+ðªâ¢(1A2))(1+ðªâ¢(1A1))â¢(1+ðªâ¢(1A2))=(ðº~x)i,jâ¢(1+ðªâ¢(Ïw2))â¢(1+ðªâ¢(1W)).
This concludes the proof of Lemma 1. â

Given that Ï-1â¢(z) is unbounded for z=0 or z=1, we consider another truncation: ÏBâ²-1â¢(z):=minâ¡{maxâ¡{Ï-1â¢(z),-Bâ²},Bâ²}, where Bâ²=2â¢logâ¡(2â¢expâ¡(B)+1). This choice of Bâ² guarantees that over ðW, |ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))|<Bâ² for all j=1,â¯,N, k=1,â¯,K and l=1,â¯,L: and thus ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))=Ï-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j)) on ðW.

From Lemma 1, the bias and variance of the maximum likelihood estimators, d^j and (ðº^x)i,j are upper-bounded, if those of d~j and (ðº~x)i,j are bounded:(16)|biasâ¡(d^j)|â¤|biasâ¡(d~j)|+Î¶j,Varâ¡(d^j)â¤Varâ¡(d~j)+Î¶~j,and(17)|biasâ¡((ðº^x)i,j)|â¤|biasâ¡((ðº~x)i,j)|+Ï i,j,Varâ¡((ðº^x)i,j)â¤Varâ¡((ðº~x)i,j)+Ï ~i,j,where Î¶j, Î¶~j, Ï i,j and Ï ~i,j represent terms that are ðªâ¢(Ïw2) or ðªâ¢(1W) . Thus, we seek to derive the performance bounds of d~j and (ðº~x)i,j.

sec.title: Bounding the bias ofÂ d^j
sec.p: Let us first consider d~j. Note that:(18)|biasâ¡(d~j)|:=|E[d~j]âdj|=(a)|E[d~jâ(dOracle)j]|â¤(b)1Lâk=1KsWk2âk,l=1K,L|sWk|E[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âxWk,l(j)|],where (a) holds since the Oracle estimator, (dOracle)j=1Lâ¢âk=1KsWk2â¢âk,l=1K,LsWkâ¢(xWk,l(j)-Î¼x(j)) (i.e., observing ð±t,l directly) is unbiased and (b) follows through the application of Jensenâs inequality and triangle inequality. To simplify this bound, the triangle inequality yields:(19)ð¼â¢[|ÏBâ²-1â¢(n~Wk,l(j))-xWk,l(j)|]â¤ð¼â¢[|ÏBâ²-1â¢(n~Wk,l(j))-ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))|]+ð¼â¢[|ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))-xWk,l(j)|].

Then, to bound each of these terms, we establish a piece-wise linear Lipschitz-type bound on ÏBâ²-1â¢(z). First, consider the first term ð¼â¢[|ÏBâ²-1â¢(n~Wk,l(j))-ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))|]. We seek to upper-bound this expectation by bounding |ÏBâ²-1â¢(n~Wk,l(j))-ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))| via the following technical lemma:

Lemma 2.Â Conditioned on event AW, the following bound holds for all j=1,â¯,N, k=1,â¯,K and l=1,â¯,L:Îµâ¢(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j)):=|ÏBâ²-1â¢(n~Wk,l(j))-ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))|â¤gâ¢(B)â¢|n~Wk,l(j)-nÂ¯Wk,l(j)|,wheregâ¢(B)=maxâ¡{4â¢(1+expâ¡(B))2,4â¢expâ¡(-B)â¢logâ¡(2â¢expâ¡(B)+1)â¢(1+(2â¢expâ¡(B)+1)2)}.

Proof of Lemma 2. First, consider the case nÂ¯Wk,l(j)â¤0.5. We bound the function Îµâ¢(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j)) in a piece-wise fashion as follows. Note that ÏBâ²-1â¢(n~Wk,l(j)) is convex for n~Wk,l(j)â¥0.5 and concave for n~Wk,l(j)â¤0.5. Thus, it immediately follows that for n~Wk,l(j)â¤nÂ¯Wk,l(j), Îµâ¢(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j)) is convex and hence:(20)Îµ(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j))â¤|Bâ²+ÏBâ²â1(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))||nÂ¯Wk,l(j)â11+expâ¡(Bâ²)|(nÂ¯Wk,l(j)ân~Wk,l(j)).

Furthermore, for nÂ¯Wk,l(j)â¤n~Wk,l(j)â¤0.5, Îµ(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j)) is concave, and hence is bounded by the tangent at nÂ¯Wk,l(j):(21)Îµ(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j))â¤1nÂ¯Wk,l(j)(1ânÂ¯Wk,l(j))(n~Wk,l(j)ânÂ¯Wk,l(j)).
Finally, for the case of n~Wk,l(j)â¥0.5, consider the line,(22)h(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j)):=|Bâ²âÏBâ²â1(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))||11+expâ¡(âBâ²)ânÂ¯Wk,l(j)|(n~Wk,l(j)ânÂ¯Wk,l(j)).

From the convexity of Îµ(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j)), h(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j)) upper bounds Îµ(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j)) for n~Wk,l(j)â¥0.5, since h(0.5,nÂ¯Wk,l(j))â¥Îµ(0.5,nÂ¯Wk,l(j)) for nÂ¯Wk,l(j)â¤0.5. Combining the piece-wise bounds in Equation 20, Equation 21 and Equation 22, we conclude that for nÂ¯Wk,l(j)â¤0.5:(23)Îµâ¢(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j))â¤g~â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j),Bâ²)â¢|n~Wk,l(j)-nÂ¯Wk,l(j)|,whereg~â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j),Bâ²)=maxâ¡{1nÂ¯Wk,l(j)â¢(1-nÂ¯Wk,l(j)),|Bâ²+ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))||nÂ¯Wk,l(j)-11+expâ¡(Bâ²)|,|Bâ²-ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))||11+expâ¡(-Bâ²)-nÂ¯Wk,l(j)|}.
Due to the symmetry of Îµâ¢(n~Wk,l(j),nÂ¯Wk,l(j)), the same bound in Equation 23 can be established for nÂ¯Wk,l(j)>0.5 as well.

Then, using |ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))|â¤Bâ² and conditioning on event ðW, we simplify this bound as:g~â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j),Bâ²)â¤maxâ¡{4â¢(1+expâ¡(B))2,4â¢Bâ²â¢(1+expâ¡(Bâ²))â¢(1+expâ¡(B))expâ¡(Bâ²)-(2â¢expâ¡(B)+1)}.

Finally, based on the fact that Bâ²=2â¢logâ¡(2â¢expâ¡(B)+1), the latter is further upper bounded as:g~â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j),Bâ²)â¤gâ¢(B),wheregâ¢(B)=maxâ¡{4â¢(1+expâ¡(B))2,4â¢expâ¡(-B)â¢logâ¡(2â¢expâ¡(B)+1)â¢(1+(2â¢expâ¡(B)+1)2)}.
This concludes the proof of Lemma 2. â
Following Lemma 2, by conditioning on the event ðW we have:(24)ð¼ðWâ¢[|ÏBâ²-1â¢(n~Wk,l(j))-ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))|]â¤gâ¢(B)â¢ð¼ðWâ¢[|n~Wk,l(j)-nÂ¯Wk,l(j)|].

Then, we note that:(25)E[|n~Wk,l(j)ânÂ¯Wk,l(j)|]â¤(c)E[|n~Wk,l(j)ânÂ¯Wk,l(j)|2]=(d)Ïw1+Î±2W,where in (c) we have used the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, and in (d) we have used the fact that the observation noise across the W time instances is i.i.d. and white. From the bounds in Equation 24 and Equation 25, we conclude that the first expectation in Equation 19, conditioned on event ðW is bounded as:(26)EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÏBâ²â1(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))|]â¤g(B)EðW[|n~Wk,l(j)ânÂ¯Wk,l(j)|]â¤g(B)Ïw1+Î±2WP(ðW).

The foregoing sequence of reasoning similarly follows for ð¼â¢[|ÏBâ²-1â¢(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))-xWk,l(j)|], since 11+expâ¡(B)â¤Ïâ¢(xWk,l(j))â¤1-11+expâ¡(B) for k=1,â¯,K, l=1,â¯,L and j=1,â¯,N (as a consequence of |xWk,l(j)|<B for k=1,â¯,K, l=1,â¯,L and j=1,â¯,N, conditioned on ðW). Accordingly, we derive the upper bound on the second term in Equation 19, conditioned on event ðW:(27)EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))âxWk,l(j)|]â¤g(B)EðW[|nÂ¯Wk,l(j)âÏ(xWk,l(j))|]â¤(e)g(B)WP(ðW)E[(âw=1Wn(kâ1)W+w,l(j)âWÏ(xWk,l(j)))2]=(f)g(B)WP(ðW)E[WÏ(xWk,l(j))(1âÏ(xWk,l(j)))]â¤(g)g(B)2WP(ðW),where (e) follows from the application of Jensenâs inequality, (f) follows from the formula for the variance of a Binomial random variable, and (g) follows from the inequality Ï(xWk,l(j))(1âÏ(xWk,l(j)))â¤1/4, for Ïâ¢(xWk,l(j))â[0,1]. Combining the results in Equation 26 and Equation 27, the overall expectation in Equation 19, conditioned on the event ðW is upper-bounded by:(28)ð¼ðWâ¢[|ÏBâ²-1â¢(n~Wk,l(j))-xWk,l(j)|]â¤2â¢gâ¢(B)Wâ¢(Ïwâ¢1+Î±2+12),where we have lower bounded the probability of the event ðW by 1/2(that is, â¢ââ¢(ðW)>1/2)Â (thatÂ is,Â P(ðW)>1/2). Thus, from Equation 18 and Equation 28 we derive:|biasðWâ¡(d~j)|â¤2g(B)W(Ïw1+Î±2+12)âk,l=1K,L|sWk|Lâk=1KsWk2â¤(h)2g(B)ÏsW(Ïw1+Î±2+12),where in (h) we have used the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality âk=1K|sWk|â¤Kâ¢âk=1KsWk2 while defining Ïs2:=1Kâ¢âk=1KsWk2.

Then, for Bâ¥2.5, we have gâ¢(B)=4â¢(1+expâ¡(B))2 and Bâ²=2â¢logâ¡(2â¢expâ¡(B)+1)â¤3â¢B. Let B:=Ïmâ¢8â¢qâ¢logâ¡W for some q>164. Further, for some Ïµ<1/2, suppose that:(29)logâ¡Wâ¥max{logâ¡(8KLN/Î·)q,32Ïm2qÏµ2,2logâ¡(64q)1â2Ïµ,max{6.25,4(âÎ¼xââ+maxk,j{Â |sWkdj|Â })2}8qÏm2,logâ¡2}.

Under these conditions,Â (30)g(B)â¤4(1+expâ¡(Ïm8qlogâ¡W))2â¤(i)16expâ¡(2Ïm8qlogâ¡W)â¤16WÏµ,where in (i) we have used the fact that exâ¥1 for xâ¥0. Thus, under the conditions in Equation 29, we have:(31)|biasðWâ¡(d~j)|ââ¤32Ïsâ¢W1-2â¢Ïµâ¢(Ïwâ¢1+Î±2+12).
Finally, from Equation 16 and Equation 31, we conclude that:|biasðWâ¡(d^j)|ââ¤1W1-2â¢Ïµâ¢C1â¢(2â¢Ïwâ¢1+Î±2+1)+ðªâ¢(Ïw2)+ðªâ¢(1W),where C1:=16Ïs.

sec.title: Bounding the variance ofÂ d^j
sec.p: Next, we prove the upper bound on the variance of the maximum likelihood estimator, d^j. To that end, we upper-bound the variance of d~j. First, using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have:(32)Varâ¡(d~j):=ð¼â¢[|d~j-ð¼â¢[d~j]|2]â¤{ð¼â¢[|d~j-(dOracle)j|2]+Varâ¡((dOracle)j)}2.

Then, we upper-bound the conditional second moment of |d~j-(dOracle)j| using the same techniques as we used in bounding the first moment. Accordingly, we get:(33)EðW[|d~jâ(dOracle)j|2]=1(Lâk=1KsWk2)2EðW[|âk,l=1K,LsWk(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âxWk,l(j))|2]â¤(j)1(Lâk=1KsWk2)2{âk,l=1K,L|sWk|EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âxWk,l(j)|2]}2â¤(k){2g(B)ÏsW(Ïw1+Î±2+12)}2,where in (j), we have used the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and (k) follows from ð¼ðWâ¢[|ÏBâ²-1â¢(n~Wk,l(j))-xWk,l(j)|2]â¤2â¢(gâ¢(B))2Wâ¢(Ïwâ¢1+Î±2+12)2, which can be proven by the same techniques as before.
Next, we note that the variance of the Oracle estimator (dOracle)j is given by:(34)Varâ¡((dOracle)j)=1(Lâk=1KsWk2)2âk,l=1K,LsWk2Varâ¡((xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)))=(Î£x)j,jLâk=1KsWk2=(Î£x)j,jLKÏs2.
Combining Equation 32, Equation 33, and Equation 34, we can upper-bound the conditional variance of d~j following Equation 32Â as:VarðWâ¡(d~j)â¤(Î£x)j,jKLÏs2(1âÎ·)+2g(B)ÏsW(Ïw1+Î±2+12).

Then, following Equation 16, under the conditions for W in Equation 29, we conclude the proof of the conditional variance of d^j:(35)VarðWâ¡(d^j)â¤(Î£x)j,jKLÏs2(1âÎ·)+1W1â2ÏµC2(2Ïw1+Î±2+1)+ðª(Ïw2)+ðª(1W),where C2:=8â¢2Ïs.

sec.title: Bounding the bias of (ðº^x)i,j
sec.p: Next, following the foregoing techniques, we upper-bound the bias and variance of the noise covariance estimator (ðº^x)i,j. To that end, we first note:(36)|biasâ¡((Î£~x)i,j)|:=|E[(Î£~x)i,j]â(Î£x)i,j|â¤(l)|E[(Î£~x)i,jâ(Î£Oracle)i,j]|+|biasâ¡((Î£Oracle)i,j)|,where (l) follows from the triangle inequality, with the Oracle noise covariance estimator (i.e., observing ð±t,l directly), being defined as:(Î£Oracle)i,j=1KLâk,l=1K,L(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i)âsWk(dOracle)i)(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)âsWk(dOracle)j).

Then, to simplify the first term in Equation 36, we use similar techniques as before. Accordingly,(37)|E[(Î£~x)i,jâ(Î£Oracle)i,j]|=|E[1KLâk,l=1KL(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)âsWkd~iÂ )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÎ¼x(j)âsWkd~j)â1KLâk,l=1KL(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i)âsWk(dOracle)i)(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)âsWk(dOracle)j)]|â¤(m)1KLâk,l=1K,LE[|(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)Â )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÎ¼x(j)Â )â(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i))(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j))|]+1KL2âk=1KsWk2E[|âk,l=1K,LsWk(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i))âkâ²,lâ²=1K,LsWkâ²(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²,lâ²(j))âÎ¼x(j))ââk,l=1K,LsWk(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i))âkâ²,lâ²=1K,LsWkâ²(xWkâ²,lâ²(j)âÎ¼x(j))|],where (m) follows through the application of Jensenâs inequality and triangle inequality. Next, conditioned on the event ðWÂ we have:(38)EðW[|(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)Â )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÎ¼x(j)Â )â(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i))(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j))|]â¤EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âxWk,l(i)xWk,l(j)|]+Î¼x(j)EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âxWk,l(i)|]+Î¼x(i)EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âxWk,l(j)|]â¤EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÏBâ²â1(nÂ¯Wk,l(i))ÏBâ²â1(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))|]+EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(nÂ¯Wk,l(i))ÏBâ²â1(nÂ¯Wk,l(j))âxWk,l(i)xWk,l(j)|]+2Î¼mEðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âxWk,l(j)|]â¤2g(B)Ïw1+Î±2W(g(B)Ïw1+Î±2W+4logâ¡(2expâ¡(B)+1))+2g(B)W{g(B)4W+B}+4Î¼mg(B)W(Ïw1+Î±2+12),where Î¼m=âÎ¼xââ and we have used Bâ²=2logâ¡(2expâ¡(B)+1). Similarly, conditioned on the event ðWÂ the second term in Equation 37 can be bounded as:(39)EðW[|âk,l=1K,LsWk(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)Â )âkâ²,lâ²=1K,LsWkâ²(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²,lâ²(j))âÎ¼x(j)Â )ââk,l=1K,LsWk(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i))âkâ²,lâ²=1K,LsWkâ²(xWkâ²,lâ²(j)âÎ¼x(j))|]â¤âk,kâ²,l,lâ²=1K,K,L,L|sWksWkâ²|EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²,lâ²(j))âxWk,l(i)xWkâ²,lâ²(j)|]+Î¼x(i)âk,kâ²,l,lâ²=1K,K,L,L|sWksWkâ²|EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²,lâ²(j))âxWkâ²,lâ²(j)|]+Î¼x(j)âk,kâ²,l,lâ²=1K,K,L,L|sWksWkâ²|EðW[|ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âxWk,l(i)|](40)â¤(Lâk=1K|sWk|)2{2g(B)Ïw1+Î±2W(g(B)Ïw1+Î±2W+4logâ¡(2expâ¡(B)+1))+2g(B)W{g(B)4W+B}+4Î¼mg(B)W(Ïw1+Î±2+12)}.

Then, by combining the bounds in Equation 38 and Equation 40 and using an instance of Cauchy-Schwarz inequality (âk=1K|sWk|)2â¤Kâk=1KsWk2, we see that the bound in Equation 37 conditioned on the event ðWÂ can be expressed as:(41)|EðW[(Î£~x)i,jâ(Î£Oracle)i,j]|â¤4g(B)Ïw1+Î±2W(g(B)Ïw1+Î±2W+4logâ¡(2expâ¡(B)+1)+2Î¼m)+4g(B)W{g(B)4W+B+Î¼m}.
Next, we see that the oracle estimator follows an Inverse Wishart distribution, that is KLÎ£Oracleâ¼InvWishNâ¡(Î£x,KLâ1). Therefore, we get:E[Î£Oracle]=(KLâ1)KLÎ£x.
Thus, the bias of the oracle estimator is given by:(42)|biasâ¡((Î£Oracle)i,j)|=1KL|(Î£x)i,j|.

Combining the results in Equation 41 and Equation 42, the bias of (Î£~x)i,j can be bounded as:(43)|biasðWâ¡((Î£~x)i,j)|â¤|(Î£x)i,j|KL(1âÎ·)+4g(B)Ïw1+Î±2W(4logâ¡(2expâ¡(B)+1)+2Î¼m)+4g(B)W(B+Î¼m)+ðª(g(B)2W).

Finally, under the conditions for W in Equation 29, the latter inequality simplifies to:(44)|biasðWâ¡((Î£~x)i,j)|â¤(n)|(Î£x)i,j|KL(1âÎ·)+Bg(B)W(28Ïw1+Î±2+6)+ðª(g(B)2W)â¤(o)|(Î£x)i,j|KL(1âÎ·)+64Ïm2qlogâ¡WW1â2Ïµ(14Ïw1+Î±2+3)+ðª(1W1â2Ïµ),where in (n) we have used 2logâ¡(2expâ¡(B)+1)â¤3B and B>2Î¼m and in (o) we have used Bg(B)â¤16LÏµÏm8qlogâ¡L, which follows from Equation 30. Thus, following Equation 17 we derive the bound on the bias of the maximum likelihood estimator:|biasðWâ¡((Î£^x)i,j)|â¤|(Î£x)i,j|KL(1âÎ·)+logâ¡WW1â2ÏµC3(14Ïw1+Î±2+3)+ðª(Ïw2)+ðª(1W1â2Ïµ),where C3:=64Ïm2q.

sec.title: Bounding the variance ofÂ (Î£^x)i,j
sec.p: Next, we establish an upper bound on the variance of the maximum likelihood estimator of the noise covariance. To that end, we upper-bound the variance of (ðº~x)i,j. First, using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we get:(45)Varâ¡((Î£~x)i,j):=E[|(Î£~x)i,jâE[(Î£~x)i,j]|2]â¤{E[|(Î£~x)i,jâ(Î£Oracle)i,j|2]+Varâ¡((Î£Oracle)i,j)}2.

Then, we upper-bound the conditional second moment of |(Î£~x)i,jâ(Î£Oracle)i,j| using the same techniques used in bounding its first moment. Accordingly, we derive:(46)EðW[|(Î£~x)i,jâ(Î£Oracle)i,j|2]=1K2L2EðW[{âk,l=1K,L((ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)âsWkd~iÂ )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÎ¼x(j)âsWkd~jÂ )â(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i)âsWk(dOracle)i)(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)âsWk(dOracle)j))}2]â¤1K2L2{âk,l=1K,L{EðW[((ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)âsWkd~iÂ )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÎ¼x(j)âsWKd~jÂ )â(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i)âsWk(dOracle)i)(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)âsWk(dOracle)j))2]}12}2,where the last bound follows from the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality. Then, we derive:(47)EðW[{(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)âsWkd~iÂ )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÎ¼x(j)âsWkd~jÂ )â(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i)âsWk(dOracle)i)(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)âsWk(dOracle)j)}2]=EðW[{(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)âsWk1Lâkâ²=1KsWkâ²2âkâ²,lâ²=1K,LsWkâ²(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²,lâ²(i))âÎ¼x(i)Â )Â )Ã(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÎ¼x(j)âsWk1Lâkâ²â²=1KsWkâ²â²2âkâ²â²,lâ²â²=1K,LsWkâ²â²(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²â²,lâ²â²(j))âÎ¼x(j)Â )Â )â(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i)âsWk1Lâkâ²=1KsWkâ²2âkâ²,lâ²=1K,LsWkâ²(xWkâ²,lâ²(i)âÎ¼x(i)Â )Â )Ã(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)âsWk1Lâkâ²â²=1KsWkâ²â²2âkâ²â²,lâ²â²=1K,LsWkâ²â²(xWkâ²â²,lâ²â²(j)âÎ¼x(j)Â )Â )}2]=EðW[{((ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)Â )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÎ¼x(j)Â )â(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i))(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)))âsWkLâkâ²â²=1KsWkâ²â²2âkâ²â²,lâ²â²=1K,LsWkâ²â²{(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(i))âÎ¼x(i)Â )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²â²,lâ²â²(j))âÎ¼x(j)Â )â(xWk,l(i)âÎ¼x(i))(xWkâ²â²,lâ²â²(j)âÎ¼x(j))}âsWkLâkâ²=1KsWkâ²2âkâ²,lâ²=1K,LsWkâ²{(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²,lâ²(i))âÎ¼x(i)Â )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wk,l(j))âÎ¼x(j)Â )â(xWkâ²,lâ²(i)âÎ¼x(i))(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j))}+sWk2L2âkâ²,kâ²â²=1K,KsWkâ²2sWkâ²â²2âkâ²,kâ²â²,lâ²,lâ²â²=1K,LsWkâ²sWkâ²â²{(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²,lâ²(i))âÎ¼x(i)Â )(ÏBâ²â1(n~Wkâ²â²,lâ²â²(j))âÎ¼x(j)Â )â(xWkâ²,lâ²(i)âÎ¼x(i))(xWkâ²â²,lâ²â²(j)âÎ¼x(j))}}2]â¤2(g(B))2W(Ïw1+Î±2+12)2(g(B)W(Ïw1+Î±2+12)+2(B+Î¼m))2Ã(1+sWkLâkâ²=1KsWkâ²Lâkâ²=1KsWkâ²2+sWkLâkâ²â²=1KsWkâ²â²Lâkâ²â²=1KsWkâ²â²2+sWk2Lâkâ²=1KsWkâ²Lâkâ²â²=1KsWkâ²â²L2âkâ²=1KsWkâ²2âkâ²â²=1KsWkâ²â²2)2.

Using the final bound of Equation 47 in Equation 46, we get:(48)EðW[|(Î£~x)i,jâ(Î£Oracle)i,j|2]â¤2g(B)W(Ïw1+Î±2+12)(g(B)W(Ïw1+Î±2+12)+2(B+Î¼m))Ã1KL(KL+Lâk=1K|sWk|âkâ²=1K|sWkâ²|âkâ²=1KsWkâ²2+Lâk=1K|sWk|âkâ²â²=1K|sWkâ²â²|âkâ²â²=1KsWkâ²â²2+Lâk=1KsWk2âkâ²=1K|sWkâ²|âkâ²â²=1K|sWkâ²â²|âkâ²=1KsWkâ²2âkâ²â²=1KsWkâ²â²2)â¤42g(B)W(Ïw1+Î±2+12)(g(B)W(Ïw1+Î±2+12)+2(B+Î¼m)),where the last inequality follows from an instance of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, thatÂ is (âk=1K|sWk|)2â¤Kâk=1KsWk2.
Then, following the observation KLÂ Î£Oracleâ¼InvWishNâ¡(Î£x,KLâ1), we derive the variance of (Î£Oracle)i,j:(49)Varâ¡((Î£Oracle)i,j)=Î´i,j2=(KLâ1)((Î£x)i,j2+(Î£x)i,i(Î£x)j,j)K2L2.

Combining Equation 45, Equation 48 and Equation 49, we express the upper bound on the conditional variance of (Î£~x)i,j as:VarðWâ¡((Î£~x)i,j)â¤11âÎ·Î´i,j+82g(B)W(B+Î¼m)(Ïw1+Î±2+12)+ðª(g(B)2W).

Then, following Equation 17 and the conditions in Equation 29, we conclude the proof of the upper bound on the conditional variance of (Î£^x)i,j:VarðWâ¡((Î£^x)i,j)â¤11âÎ·Î´i,j+logâ¡WW1â2ÏµC4(2Ïw1+Î±2+1)+ðª(Ïw2)+ðª(1W1â2Ïµ),where C4:=384Ïmq.
Finally, it only remains to prove that the event ðW occurs with high probability for sufficiently large W:

Lemma 3.Â The probability of occurrence of the eventðW={|xWk,l(j)|â¤BÂ andÂ 12(1+expâ¡(B))â¤nÂ¯Wk,l(j)â¤1â12(1+expâ¡(B))Â forÂ j=1,â¯,N,k=1,â¯,KÂ andÂ l=1,â¯,L}is upper-bounded as follows:P(ðW)â¥1âÎ·,for some constant 0<Î·â¤1/2 satisfying the conditions of Equation (29).
Proof of Lemma 3.
First, using the union bound, we have:(50)P(ðW)â¥1ââk,l,j=1K,L,N{P(|xWk,l(j)|>B)+P(nÂ¯Wk,l(j)<12(1+expâ¡(B)))+P(nÂ¯Wk,l(j)>1â12(1+expâ¡(B)))}.

Next, we bound the probabilities on the right hand side using Chernoffâs inequality (Boucheron et al., 2013). First, note that:P(xWk,l(j)>B)=P(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)âsWkdj>BâÎ¼x(j)âsWkdj)â¤(p)P(xWk,l(j)âÎ¼x(j)âsWkdj>B2)â¤(q)expâ¡(âB28Ïm2),where (p) follows if B>2(âÎ¼xââ+maxk,j{Â |sWkdj|Â }) (which will hold under the conditions in Equation 29) and (q) has been derived by applying the Chernoffâs bound on the Gaussian random variable xWk,l(j). From the same reasoning, we see that P(xWk,l(j)<âB)â¤expâ¡(âB28Ïm2). Combining these two results, we get the upper bound:(51)P(|xWk,l(j)|>B)â¤2expâ¡(âB28Ïm2).

Next, note that:(52)P(nÂ¯Wk,l(j)<12(1+expâ¡(B)))â¤(r)P(nÂ¯Wk,l(j)âÏ(xWk,l(j))<â12(1+expâ¡(B)))â¤(s)expâ¡(âW16(1+expâ¡(B))2),where (r) follows from the observation 11+expâ¡(B)<Ï(xWk,l(j)) (which is a consequence of |xWk,l(j)|<B). Then, we note that the zero-mean random variable nÂ¯Wk,l(j)âÏ(xWk,l(j)) is sub-Gaussian with variance factor 2W. Thus, using the Chernoffâs inequality on sub-Gaussian random variables (Boucheron et al., 2013), we derive the upper-bound (s) in Equation 52. In a similar fashion, based on the observation Ï(xWk,l(j))<1â11+expâ¡(B), we conclude the bound:(53)P(nÂ¯Wk,l(j)>1â12(1+expâ¡(B)))â¤expâ¡(âW16(1+expâ¡(B))2).

By combining the bounds in Equation 51, Equation 52, and Equation 53, the upper bound on P(ðW) in Equation 50 takes the form:P(ðW)â¥1â2KLNexpâ¡(âW16(1+expâ¡(B))2)â2KLNexpâ¡(âB28Ïm2).

Finally, under the assumptions in Equation 29, we further simplify this bound as:P(ðW)â¥1â2KLNexpâ¡(âW1âÏµ64)â2KLNWqâ¥1â4KLNWq,where we have used Wâ¥2 (which gives logâ¡Wâ¥2logâ¡logâ¡W) and logâ¡Wâ¥2logâ¡(64q)1â2Ïµ to show that W1âÏµ64â¥qlogâ¡W. Thus, logâ¡Wâ¥logâ¡(8KLN/Î·)q ensures that P(ðW)â¥1âÎ·, for 0<Î·â¤12. â Â
This concludes the proof of Theorem 1.â

sec.title: Adapting the proposed signal and noise correlation estimates to spiking observations
sec.p: While Algorithm 1 takes two-photon fluorescence observations as input and produces estimates of signal and noise correlation as output, it is possible to adapt it to spiking observations obtained by electrophysiology recordings. The resulting algorithm is obtained by simplifying the variational inference procedure in Algorithm 1 and is given below for completeness:

boxed-text.p: Our editorial process produces two outputs: i) public reviews designed to be posted alongside the preprint for the benefit of readers; ii) feedback on the manuscript for the authors, including requests for revisions, shown below. We also include an acceptance summary that explains what the editors found interesting or important about the work.

body.p: This study establishes a new method for more precise estimation of pairwise noise and signal correlations in two-photon calcium imaging, by modeling generically the influence of calcium dynamics and subtracting the interaction between response signals and variability when the trial number is low. The accuracy of this new estimator is demonstrated here for the mouse auditory cortex, but this tool will find useful applications on a large diversity of datasets.

Thank you for submitting your article "Direct Extraction of Signal and Noise Correlations from Two-Photon Calcium Imaging of Ensemble Neuronal Activity" for consideration by eLife. Your article has been reviewed by 2 peer reviewers, including Brice Bathellier as the Reviewing Editor and Reviewer #1. and the evaluation has been overseen by Barbara Shinn-Cunningham as the Senior Editor. The reviewers have discussed their reviews with one another, and the Reviewing Editor has drafted this to help you prepare a revised submission.
Essential revisions:

Both reviewers agree on the quality of the method proposed in this study and it potential for assessing correlations in two-photon calcium imaging data. However, two points should be carefully addressed according to the comments below. First the authors should better explain what aspect of your method is key for your approach to outperform others methods. Second, the authors should better explore the behavior of your method on data that does not fulfil the core assumptions you make (uncorrelated noise, LN response model).

1. Surrogate data use a measurement noise model that has no temporal correlations. This is not the case in real two-photon imaging data, which include both correlation-free noise (photon count statistics) and temporally (and spatially) correlated artefacts. As in Deneux et al. 2016 (cited in the paper), the authors should provide simulations with different types of noise and show how this affects their correlation estimates. Is it still more robust than more classical methods?

2. Another simplifying assumption used by the authors is their model of spiking activity which is composed of a linear receptive field followed by a non-linear mapping function. Several papers have shown that this only imperfectly models neural responses (e.g. to sound in auditory cortex). There are, in fact in real neural data, non-linearities that are more complex than what the mapping function can capture. How does this impact their estimate? The authors should simulate this with e.g. a multilayer network (two-layer linear non-linear cascade, deep net) or simulate neurons that respond to the quadratic sum of the output of several linear filter (see e.g. recent work by the Shamma and colleagues).

3. There is a lack of intuition about the key aspects in their approach that makes it overperform other methods. This should be introduced in the results and/or discussion to better guide and convince the reader.

It is crucial that any end-user be able to get a clear picture of the conditions under which the method can or cannot be applied before diving in. The fact that such an applicability domain is not well defined is a major concern. Notably, each Real Data Study presented in the paper uses a preliminary selection of "highly active cells" (1rst study: N = 16; 2nd study: N = 10; 3rd study: N~20 per field), as the authors succinctly discuss that performance is expected to degrade "in the regime of extremely low spiking rate and high observation noise" (l. 518-519). But no precise criteria are provided to specify what is meant by "highly active cells". On the other hand, the authors also assume that there is at most one spiking event per time frame for each neuron, which seems to exclude bursting neurons. The latter assumption seems to be a challenge with respect to the example traces shown on Figure 4C (âF/F reaches 400%) and on Figure 6C (âF/F reaches 100%), considering that the GCaMP6s signal for a single spike is expected to peak below 10-20%. This forces the authors to take a scaling factor of the observations A = 1 x I (Real Data Study 1 and 3) or A = 0.75 x I (Real Data Study 2) compared to the A = 0.1 x I taken in the Simulation Studies. Therefore, it looks like if the Real Data Studies were performed on mainly bursting cells and each burst was counted as one spiking event. A detailed discussion of the usable range of firing rates, whether in spike or burst units, as well as the usable range of SNR should be added to the main text to allow future users to assess the suitability of their data for this analysis.

4. Another parameter seems to be set by the authors on a criterion that is unclear to me: the number of time lags R to be included in the sound stimulus vector st. It seems to act as a memory of the past trajectory of the stimulus and probably serves to enhance the effect of stimulus onset/offset relative to the rest of the sound presentation. It is consistent with the known tendency of neurons in the primary auditory cortex to respond to these abrupt changes in sound power. However, this R is set at 2 in the Simulation Study 1, whereas it is set at 25, in the Real Data Studies 1 and 3, and to 40 in the Real Data Study 2. What leads to these differences escaped to me and should be explained more clearly.

5. This memory of the past stimulus trajectory appears to be specific to the proposed method and is not accounted for in the 2-stage Pearson estimation, for example. Since it probably helps to reflect the common sensitivity of neurons to onset/offset, it alone provides an advantage to the proposed method over the 2-stage Pearson estimation. It would be instructive to also perform this comparison with R set to 1 to get an idea of the magnitude of this advantage.

disp-quote.p: Both reviewers agree on the quality of the method proposed in this study and it potential for assessing correlations in two-photon calcium imaging data. However, two points should be carefully addressed according to the comments below. First the authors should better explain what aspect of your method is key for your approach to outperform others methods. Second, the authors should better explore the behavior of your method on data that does not fulfil the core assumptions you make (uncorrelated noise, LN response model).

body.p: We would like to thank the reviewing editor for his supportive stance towards our work, and for clearly summarizing the feedback from both reviewers. Based on the comments and suggestions of the two reviewers, we have made several changes to our manuscript that substantially and constructively addresses both of these key points, as we describe next.

This is not the case in real two-photon imaging data, which include both correlation-free noise (photon count statistics) and temporally (and spatially) correlated artefacts. This result is included in a new subsection called âAnalysis of Robustness with respect to Modeling Assumptionsâ (Pages 6-7).

body.p: To address this comment, we have now included the sources of performance gap between our proposed method and existing ones in the revised Discussion section, highlighting the key aspects of our method that makes it outperform existing approaches (Pages 17-18). We have also added a new subsection to Methods called âGuidelines for model parameter settingsâ that includes our rationale and criteria for choosing the number of neurons (N), stimulus integration window length (R), observation noise covariance (Î£w), scaling matrix A, state transition parameter (Î±), and mean of the latent noise process (Î¼x) (Page 24). Finally, we have performed new simulation studies to evaluate the effects of SNR and firing rate on the performance of the proposed method (Pages 6-7), and closely inspected the performance of our method under rapid increase of firing rate (Page 10).

body.p: To address this comment, we have now discussed the advantage of including the stimulus history in our model and probed the sensitivity of our estimates to the choice of R (including R = 1) in Figure 4âfigure supplement 1 (Page 10).

body.p: Thank you for this suggestion. As explained earlier in response to the public portion of Reviewer 1âs comments, motivated by this suggestion, we have substantially enhanced our performance analyses in the revised manuscript and compiled them in a new subsection titled âAnalysis of Robustness with respect to Modeling Assumptionsâ for better clarity and consistency.

Specifically, we considered two observation noise model mismatch conditions, namely, white noise + low frequency drift and pink noise, similar to the treatment in Deneux et al. (2016). For each noise mismatch model, we also varied the SNR level and firing rate and compared the performance of the different algorithms as reported in Figure 2âfigure supplement 6. These new analyses demonstrate that our proposed estimates outperform the existing methods, under correlated generative noise models, and also with respect to varying levels of SNR and firing rate. As clearly evident in panels C and F of Figure 2âfigure supplement 6, even though the estimated calcium concentrations are contaminated by the temporally correlated fluctuations in observation noise, the putative spikes estimated as a byproduct of our iterative method closely match the ground truth spikes, which in turn results in accurate estimates of signal and noise correlations.

To address this comment, we performed extensive simulations to evaluate the robustness of different algorithms under model mismatch conditions induced by temporal correlations of observation noise. These new analyses are included in a new subsection called âAnalysis of Robustness with respect to Modeling Assumptionsâ (Pages 6-7).

body.p: Thank you for this suggestion. As explained earlier in response to the public portion of Reviewer 1âs comments, we have addressed this comment in the revised manuscript in the new subsection titled âAnalysis of Robustness with respect to Modeling Assumptionsâ. To examine the robustness of our method with respect to model mismatch in stimulus integration, as suggested, we generated data according to a non-linear (i.e., quadratic sum of linear filters) receptive field model:but assumed a linear stimulus integration model in our inference procedure (i.e., dÌj,1=dÌj,2=0). The comparison of the correlations estimated under this setting by each method are shown in Figure 2 âfigure supplement 3. While the performance of our proposed signal correlation estimates under this setting degrade as compared to that in Figure 2 with no model mismatch, our proposed estimates still outperform the other methods and recovers the ground truth signal correlation structure reasonably well.

It is noteworthy that the model mismatch in the stimulus integration component does not affect the accuracy of noise correlation estimates in our method, as is evident from the noise correlation estimates in Figure 2âfigure supplement 3. In comparison, the biases induced in the other methods due to model mismatch and various other factors such as observation noise, temporal blurring, undermining non-linear mappings between spikes and underlying covariates, results in significantly larger errors in both signal and noise correlation estimates.

Finally, we would like to note that since our model is a baseline framework for signal and noise correlation estimation from two-photon imaging data, it has the inherent limitations of the underlying modeling assumptions such as linear receptive fields and binary spiking. However, it is possible to generalize our approach beyond linear stimulus integration by extending to non-linear models such as those parameterized by neural networks, as we have also outlined towards the end of the Discussion.

To address this comment, we performed a new simulation study to evaluate the robustness of different algorithms under model mismatch conditions induced by non-linear stimulus integration model. This result is included in a new subsection called âAnalysis of Robustness with respect to Modeling Assumptionsâ (Pages 6-7).

disp-quote.p: 3. There is a lack of intuition about the key aspects in their approach that makes it overperform other methods. This should be introduced in the results and/or discussion to better guide and convince the reader.

body.p: Thank you for pointing out this source of ambiguity. The two main sources for the observed performance gap between our proposed method and existing approaches can be summarized as follows:

1) Favorable soft decisions on the timing of spikes achieved by our method, as a byproduct of the iterative variational inference procedure: an accurate probabilistic decoding of spikes results in better estimates of the signal/noise correlations, and conversely having more accurate estimates of the signal/noise covariances improves the probabilistic characterization of spiking events. This is in contrast with both the Pearson and Two-Stage methods: in the Pearson method, spike timing is heavily blurred by the calcium decay; in the two-stage methods, erroneous hard (i.e., binary) decisions on the timing of spiking events result in biases that propagate to and contaminate the downstream signal and noise correlation estimation and thus result in significant errors.

2) Explicit modeling of the non-linear mapping from stimulus and latent noise covariates to spiking through a canonical point process model (which is in turn tied to a two-photon observation model in a multi-tier Bayesian fashion) results in robust performance under limited number of trials and observation duration. As we have shown in Appendix 1, as the number of trials L and trial duration T tend to infinity, conventional notions of signal and noise correlation indeed recover the ground truth signal and noise correlations, as the biases induced by non-linearities average out across trial repetitions. However, as shown in Figure 2âfigure supplement 2, in order to achieve comparable performance to our method using 20 trials, the conventional correlation estimates require ~1000 trials.

To address this comment, we have now included the aforementioned sources of performance gap in the revised Discussion section, highlighting the key aspects of our method that makes it outperform existing approaches (Pages 17-18).
